In order not to bother them... we walked to this place for a cup of coffee and a light breakfast the first morning we were in town.  I'm so glad we found this place.  First, the service was FANTASTIC - they were super nice!  Not only was the service great, the coffee and food we had was also very good!  We are so glad we found this place and went each morning we were in town.  And, I promise, each time we are in town, we will walk here for our morning coffee and breakfast.
author: Mike B.

description:
Health danger: the lettuce was brown and the chicken had freezer burn.

I asked for, and was politely given, a refund for my meal but no extra effort was made to make ammends or encourage me to give them another chance.

There are too many coffee shops/cafes in this city, don't waste your time or money here.
author: Hannah K.

description: Don't go hear if you're in a rush. A latte and a bagel 15 minutes!
author: Victoria O.

description:
My favorite type of brunch is of the hangover variety; when you wake up on a Sunday, bleary-eyed and dry-mouthed, with a need to atone for Saturday's sins and shenanigans. which is why we went to the Grind. And there's not much I can say about this diner-come-community coffee shop other than;
- It's semi-self-service (read: you place your order at a counter, get your own condiments and silverware, but they bus the tables).
-It's affordable and reasonably priced
-It served it's purpose in providing a safe haven to soberly rehash yesterday's details (eg; "Wait, you did WHAT?! - Where was I?!")
 
Sometimes all you need to recover is an order of pancakes with a second helping of pillow-time....at least the Grind can deliver on the first one.
author: Lady O.

description: What's not to like... lox, eggs, pancakes, coffee.  All good.  The prices are what you'd expect in any part of SF.  Counter help are kind, seating is clean.  Loved it.
author: John D.

description:
First thing, the latte and cappuccino here is always awesome. As noted by someone else the foam is always thick , sweet and awesome. 

Second, the coffee itself is not bad at all. The taste is good, and even my mom said that's one of the better espressos she's tasted around--however that was back when the son (with the slick hair) of the lady owner was still around running the place and manning the coffee--before the renovation.   

Right now the place is bright and clean after the renovation.  There are lots of tables which is good.. but also it gets crowded sometimes ! Not that it's a fault of the place, I guess too many people want to eat there.  

The girls behind the counter are always smiling, so that's awesome. Don't know their names (contrary to the other poster) but that's fine. 

They serve simple omelettes, scrabbles (a few cents cheaper than other places) and have Belgian waffles and pancakes!  We often really liked the waffles with fruid and/or the fruid with yoghurt. 

Even some of the guys cooking have been there for years! Sal.? Now isn't that good.   The air is not completely free of kitchen-frying smells, but it's OK.
author: Jordan G.

description:
We had a hankering for a nearby breakfast place with fruit and this one had good reviews.

Overall, the place was good although not memorable. It does get a positive remark in regards to not being too greasy, as some other breakfast places we have been to have fallen into that category.

The prices are good, portions are decent, without any glaring strikes against it except the waffles were a little dry (although did taste good when a piece of fruit was mixed in with the bite taken). Probably not a place we would go back to in the end, but worth checking out once.
author: Sami R.

description: Love this place. Been here a few times now. The coffee is good, the food is excellent. I have never been disappointed. They make great scrambles ( to my design), omelets and pancakes. I love going out for breakfast (I go out several days a week) and I love coming here. Friendly atmosphere, excellent service and casual ambiance. Great job to everyone at The Grind.
author: Joanne F.

description: Scrumptious scramble and solid egg white omelet. Good local place for a quick sit-down brunch on the weekends. No fuss good food - order at the counter and reasonably priced.
author: Sandra S.

description: Walking distance from my place, sunday brunch, tasty chai, outdoor seating that is dog friendly what more could I ask for?  I wouldn't drive all the way to the grind from another neighborhood just for their brunch.  But if you are in the lower haight check it out.
author: Kierstan G.

description:
Great to place to stop in and grab a bite to eat, especially if you are perusing around Lower Haight. They serve up good portions, and have a wide variety of different things to choose from.

Breakfast + Lunch stuff mainly. They have a good amount of Scrambles to choose from, pancakes, omelets, etc...more importantly they have quality sour dough toast...not that cheap stuff. Their Burgers looked good, made with Niman Ranch Beef. 

Beverages: They have a wide variety. Everything from Gatorade to  Soda's to Smoothies to Ice Tea/Lemonade to Beers

RECOMMENDATION: Try an Arnold Palmer with their Ginger Ice Tea...stuff is really good.

The spacing is open, and they have good ventilation. There is plenty of sun and a good amount of seating.
author: Nick C.

description: This place is great if you want a no frills, huge menu, good coffee, and no wait breakfast/brunch on the weekend. I like that you can order up at a counter, and their menu is huge so everyone is happy. I've had their breakfast burritos and their egg bfast sandwich. Both come with a choice of hashbrowns or homefries. Love their hashbrowns. With a coffee and you get a huge portion of food for less than $12. I've had nothing but nice people serving me.
author: San D.

description:
Two fork-fuls in, and I announced to the bf that I was in love with my breakfast. Not even joking.
I ordered the fresh lox scramble and have never, ever had something so amazing. I asked for no onions or anchovies and the request was honored, so my dish was eggs with salmon, tomatoes, avocado, and cream cheese. Yes, cream cheese sounds weird but it was sooo freakin goooood!!! The hash browns on the side were lovely as well. 
Ok but really, this scramble was amazing. I wanna go again. Now. 
Oh but question: are the coffee refills free? I was afraid to ask.
author: Emilia S.

description: Great breakfast place! I have not made it for lunch yet, but the lunch menu looks good too.  The staff has always been friendly.  We have never had to wait in line too long, but it does go out the door at peak hours.
author: Sarah G.

description: Valicia and Ashley rock. Croissant French toast and breakfast burritos rock. The cooks are rad too!!
author: Gabriel N.

description:
Walked by several times and it looked wonderful. We finally stopped in for brunch last week.

bottom line: It's a very pretty Denny's.

food clearly originates in the frozen food section and thrown on a grill with no seasoning. I was so hoping to love it but walked away knowing I would never be back. This is my first disappointing meal since I've moved to the city. 

My boyfriend says the coffee is good.
author: Rachel G.

description:
Cute set-up for quick meal or snack. They have healthy choices and pretty fresh ingredients for breakfast/brunch/lunch. 

I wish I could help this place out but my otherwise positive feelings towards this place are totally ruined by the curly black hair I found in my Veggie Delight Salad.

Not.okay.
author: julia s.

description: The perfect local coffee shop. Great coffee and good food!
author: Brian B.

description: I have been here twice and the food was bad to say the least. The staff was nice but not attentive which is alright with me. I know what to expect (service-wise) in different establishments so that doesnt  bother me. Crappy food bothers me tho. I may be back sometime in the distant future but will be more cautious with what I order.
author: Chad C.

description: I like everything about this place, coffee, food, service, wi-fi it's all good.
author: Rick L.

description:
Why can't there be a similar place in good ol' SOMA?  Came in for breakfast early on a saturday morning when it was quiet and I could take my time reading the extensive menu.

The breakfast choices are great-- had the egg white mediterreanean scramble with hash browns and a latte and it was out of this world.  So much food that I had to take some home for later.  I like the layout and outdoor seating (although does the sun ever come out in lower haight?)  Next time I'm going for the breakfast burrito and french toast because they looked quite awesome. 

staff is friendly as well. I'm a fan.
author: Sonia S.

description:
YUM! The food is delicious with fun creative names; the Haight Scram is my favorite. I LOVE that they have rye toast! I always see the same wonderful smiling ladies working the cash register and coffee bar. They are always so nice and cheerful. It is definitely a great treat seeing attentive help with smiles as this place is PACKED on the weekends. Although, I have stopped by on my bus ride to work during the week and they are still there, smiling and ready to help out. It is so nice to be greeted with that kind of service.

For me the weekends are a toss up, if it is a nice day I will stick out the wait to sit on the patio area, but on those lazy rainy weekends I enjoy calling in my order, picking it up and enjoying food from bed or the couch with a blanket and movie. Either way, it is quick happy service.
author: Misty G.

description: The Grind is my regular Sunday morning brunch place. You order at the register, and they bring your food to your table.  The food's delicious with big portions and wide selection. The place has high ceilings, lots of natural light, and basic tables and chairs. Sometimes getting a seat can be a little difficult after 11am on a Sunday but it's never too bad. I would recommend it.
author: Stuart S.

description: I love The Grind Cafe. They have excellent portion sizes of really really good food at fair prices.
author: Giovanni F.

description: There is nothing particularly offensive or unusually good about this Lower Haight neighborhood breakfast spot.  Decent coffee. Usually buzzing with people who live near by. You won't be disappointed if it's an ordinary sort of day.
author: Luke M.

description:
We were walking back from Haight-Ashbury and had to go -- really, really bad. We were at the point where we couldn't hold it any longer and The Grind Cafe was the closest restroom, so we decided to stop by and have a drink. We glanced over their menu and decided we might as well stop for lunch here.

I've become such a Yelp snob that I regularly don't eat at a place that I haven't at least read a couple of reviews on. Today was different though, I really had some bladder presser that needed relieving. The other half ordered a standard burger and a banana smoothie. I ordered the breakfast sandwich with a side of hash browns.

We found the food to be flavorless and uninspiring. I sure hit up the salt and paper shakers to spice up my hash browns. They had run out of croissants, so my breakfast sandwich was scrambled eggs and bacon between to slices of toast. I suppose I was hoping for something tasty and surprising, but all I got was a sandwich that I could have made at home. Even the smoothie was a disappointment. From the first sip you could tell that the banana was still unripened. 

It was a disappointing meal from start to finish.
author: Hugo C.

description:
The grind is a good reliable cafe. The food & people are honest.
There could be a wait on weekends, which only means
That this place is worth ir
author: Jane f.

description: I liked this place... another cool breakfast place within walking distance. I ordered the ham scram with avocado, toast and hash browns. Let me tell you, I inhaled everything. I'd put some of the scram on my toast and it'd taste even better. As always, staff was friendly and nice, atmosphere was chill, food was awesome.
author: Laura F.

description: Had the extremely delicious breakfast burrito with bacon to start off my first Memorial Day as an SF resident. Not a bad cup of joe and some nice girls, with nice smiles working behind the counter.
author: David H.

description:
Been here a few times.  It's solid.  Not great- not bad.  Pretty standard fare.

Coffee is tasty. Meals are good.  I like the breakfast burrito and other breakfast items.  If you are just popping in for a quick coffee and pastry, if you're lucky you can get leftover pastries from the day before for only $1.

One thing I dislike is that they charge you $0.50 for a refill on your coffee.  I mean, I just bought a meal for 2 people for $30, and I'm sitting in your restaurant on a Sunday morning enjoying a nice meal.  I think I deserve a free refill on principle!  I'm not sitting here with a laptop sucking up free wi-fi and unlimited coffee for 4 hours on a Tuesday.  Plus it would be nice to know that you charge $0.50 ahead of time for coffee refills- I would have gotten my coffee in a to-go cup which is definitely bigger! Or ordered a larger size in the first place for only $0.25 more.

All in all, decent spot.
author: Chris L.

description: My favorie breakfast spot in the City... started coming here when it opened years ago, and its still "got it"
author: Sarkis S.

description: Food is ok fare...customer service at the counter abominable. The brunette waif was so distracted today, flirting with a boy, she over-charged me, then short changed me when I pointed it out, then refused to cancel the transaction. They need training not only in basic customer service, but in how to ring up a transaction.
author: Jasper N.

description:
There's not many brunch spots in Lower Haight. The only other one I can think of is Kate's Kitchen and maybe Katz (but not really). Luckily with the limited number of real brunch spots in Lower Haight, The Grind is pretty good. It can get busy and open seats are hard to come by but the food is better than average, coffee is good, and there's definitely some good people watching, especially if you can get a spot outside in their front patio area. 

Some items I would recommend:
-chicken fried steak and eggs
-croissant sandwich with egg and bacon
-pancakes and eggs

...as you can tell i'm not the type to order fruit and oatmeal. I like my brunch food to be hearty and unhealthy.
author: David C.

description: This place has good salads: Cobb salad and their chicken was juicy.  I also ordered their caesar salad... which was ok, but their french fries were good.  I like the laid back atmosphere of this place.  I want to try breakfast/brunch!
author: Ting B.

description:
Some times you wake up earlier than you really should. Your eye balls are telling you that your eyes sockets are really to small for their liking, or are your eye sockets telling you that your eye balls are to big now. Hard to say.  You ponder your choices...lay here reach back into the sandmans bag and wake up later with half the day gone or raise your self from the slightly sweaty ( you know the sweaty I mean, its the one you get when you fall asleep in your clothes. Could be on a plane, a couch wherever. Its not location specific) tangled mess of sheets and duvet and go in search of the cure.
 As you untie the knot of sheets around your left leg and ponder the unanswerable question ..... 
If I cannot tie a cherry stem into a knot with my toungue while im awake how can my left leg do a double fishermans knot with the sheet while im asleep....?
But perhaps the more pressing question is what breakfast will return you to that bubbling fountain of energy and optimism and resize ones eyeballs/sockets to their previously happy status quo?
For me at least its always been a grease based remedy and invariably one is drawn to the greasiest spoon in town. I usually meet others at these establishments who seem to be pondering the same questions as I, so I assume this is a fairly common phenom.
The problem has always been matching a good grease based breakfast with a good cup of coffee. Coffee, if you can call it that, at the greasy spoon is never good. NEVER! It looks like coffee but the scent of it tells you something that the mouth will confirm shotrly after the dark liquid passes from the porcelin to the pallate.... There is less coffee bean and more ritual blood sacrifice in that cup than there should be. You know what I mean, that kind of metalic iron taste thats followed by a dull, flat uncomfortable undertone.

Today though I am happy to say that I found a very happy medium at the Grind cafe. A very good cup of coffee with just the right amount of greasy breakfast. I had the Grind scramble with house fries ( little roasty tubers) and wheat toast. The scramble was artfully bound by 2 pieces of american cheese which turn it into an egg, cheese meat burger. Very easy to handle, you just slice of a chunk, pin a roasty with your fork, dip in ketchup, place in mouth and chase with aforementioned good coffee!
Was here at 10 so no line....11 gets you a line.

So check it out. Lots of good food choices, not a greasy spoon by any means but is able to deliver the cure for eyeball resizing!
Check it out
author: Adam O.

description: Friendly neighborhood cafe with an extensive menu.  I've only eaten breakfast there, but it's always satisfying.  Even when busy, it is worth the wait.
author: Janis S.

description:
very torn between 2 and 3 stars...this place is not bad, the price is just about right for what it is, I was just not impressed.  

We came here on a Saturday, which might explain why it was so freaking busy.  After we ordered, we had to wait for a table to clear up, and we ended up bussing it ourselves.

I got a basic breakfast of eggs, toast, hashbrowns, and vegi-sausage patties.  I have to say, it's really nice that they have the meat alternatives...I'm not vegi or vegan or anything, I just really like certain vegi-patties (like the morning star ones...mmm...so good!) But the hash browns were meeh, the eggs were meah, the toast was a bit burn, but the vegi-sausage was AWESOME!!  But....BUT....lots of points because although it wasn't an impressive breakfast, it was EXACTLY what I wanted.  

We had gotten coffee earlier for the walk there, so we didn't order any at The Grind, and it seemed that everyone was more about beer drinking at 11:30 am on a Saturday, as opposed to coffee drinking.  We did get smoothies, and compared to other smoothies, I was disappointed.  (Check out the Mango Smoothie at the Moonlight Cafe in Bernal Heights...they cannot be beat!)   Also, extra points for the Grind for the fact that they offer a protein additive for the smoothies.  

All in all, I wouldn't make a point of coming back here, unless I were broke and wanting to go somewhere within walking distance from home to get breakfast.  It's also walking distance from a lot of neat places, and I believe there's probably cheap beer here.
author: Jessi K.

description: This is my Sunday a.m. go-to for breakfast.  It's always good, solid breakfast, the staff is friendly, and even though it looks crowded when you walk in on a Sunday, you can always get a set by the time you are through the line and have ordered.  My favorite - the breakfast sandwich.  Delish.
author: Karleen O.

description: Pretty new in Burlingame. Friendly staff, good coffee and nice decor. Could pay more attention to cleaning up floor & tables when, albeit messy, customers leave!
author: Judy N.

description:
I will say straight away that this review may not appeal to the masses who are probably yelping The Grind as a go-to place for brunch.  I didn't eat brunch here.  No sirree bob.  I walked an energetic pooch down to the Lower Haight to go let him let off some steam, and for me to grab a bite to eat.  30 minutes to closing time....for dinner.  I was the only one on the patio.  One coffee drinker inside.  The friendly lady at the counter let me in the cafe with the dog to order my food, and then delivered my food to me in adequate time.  I guess it helped that i was the only food the kitchen was cooking...or assembling as it were, seeing as though i got a sandwich with salad. 

Its a stark cafe.  There isn't anything super fancy about it...except its one of the only places to eat outside in Lower Haight, looks like it has a decent breakfast menu, and has a friendly staff.  I look forward to updating my review with my take on brunch service....but my dinner was delightful.  Especially now that I'm eating.
author: Lauren F.

description:
This is a few blocks walk from my abode, so on a sunny day like yesterday, perfect for a small stroll. 

It's one of those order-at-the-counter sort of places, but I found the staff to be really friendly. They have some great breakfast options, and much better than I anticipated. I'm talking 2 orders of pancakes, coffees, 2 orange juices,  side order of fruit and side order of chicken apple sausage for about $25, which I consider a brunch deal.

Snag a table on their patio, it's prime outdoor seating with plenty of people watching, good conversation for a lazy weekend afternoon.
author: Nish N.

description: The food was good. The service was a bit spotty. We ate their twice and the first time they completely forgot to make my food and then blamed it on something completely ridiculous that didn't make sense.
author: Amanda R.

description:
Slightly below average cafe in the neighborhood. Kind of sticky and ugly inside with strange lighting. I've had a bagel with lox, an egg white omelet, and, most recently, a chef's salad. Everything is just okay. It definitely doesn't stoop to the level of The People's Cafe, but it's just kind of eh. The food is rather flavorless and uninteresting.

Go to Cafe du Soleil or Cafe International instead for a pleasant ambiance and far superior menu/food quality.
author: Jill M.

description:
Mediocre...Just your average place. Not that great, but not that bad either. I don't like paying over 10 bucks for a mediocre breakfast. But that's what we did. Ugh. (Side note: go to my parents' restaurant in Daly City, and get an average greasy spoon breakfast and endless coffee for under 10 bucks!)

The place was ok. Clean upon first glance, but as I grabbed the ketchup bottle and the Tabasco sauce, my hands came away with a sticky substance attached to them. Gross. (Another side note: you can always tell how clean a restaurant is, by checking out their condiments: salt & pepper shakers, ketchup bottles, etc. If they are sticky and dirty, the place is actually not very clean.)

We ordered the Mediterranean scramble and the French toast with fruit. The scramble was 'meh', but the French toast was apparently good (they use croissants) and the coffee was pretty good also. 

Service was slow for a weekday morning with barely anyone in the place. 

Total: $23.00 two breakfast entrees, 2 coffees, tax and tip
author: Caroline C.

description: I love this place for lunch.  Great iced tea.  It is a good place to go for a quick bite, although the inside seats fill up with people on their computers who never leave...
author: Chelsea S.

description:
cute place with a decent patio for outdoor seating.

it's pretty much a coffee shop that serves meh food for cheap.  the french toast is huge and came with 6 pieces and your choice of home fries or hash browns ($6+change).  the corned beef hash is also pretty big and comes with two eggs your way...i'm not sure how much this was.

find your own seat, bus your own table.

not in a hurry to come back here unless every other breakfast place in town has a ridiculous wait time...
author: Sally T.

description: I would return to the Grind anytime I am back in SF. I had the chicken Caesar salad and a mango smoothie that was delicious! Besides the quality of the food, the atmosphere is nice and unpretentious, and the guy at the counter set a friendly tone. I noticed there were quite a bit of single diners there during the weekday afternoon I sat down so clearly this is a place people like to come to and hang.
author: Gregory D.

description: Really great for staring into your computer! Never crowded and decent coffee. Haven't tried their food.
author: Gina C.

description:
The GRIND Combo: 2 eggs, hash, sausage or bacon, french toast or pancakes

Boy: Can I have your sausage
Girl: Can I have some of your corn beef hash
Boy: Mmm my corn beef hash is good
Girl: best french toast ever
Boy: this breakfast is good. the hash isn't greasy 
Girl: I can't believe I just finished my plate

Expect a long wait for the food. 
Patio seating is available and is dog friendly :)
author: Oanh N.

description: My husband and I are always looking for a new breakfast place to try in our neighborhood, and this place always seems busy.  We got fast service (the line moved fast, that is, and the food came out fast) and the place was clean and inviting, but the food was mediocre at best- we got Joe's scramble and a breakfast burrito.  Neither had a lot of flavor- the burrito only had what little spice comes in the chorizo, and Joe's scramble was topped with two slices of what looked like Kraft american cheese.  We're not crazy cheese snobs, but the cheese squares melted on top of the scramble looked like something for a child's menu.  The prices were pretty normal for the area, too- not really a deal.
author: Kim K.

description:
2 words:  Hummus Bagel.

So it's pretty much your average coffee shop but I like the vibe in there. 

When I used to work nearby I'd eat that damn hummus bagel almost every day.  So simple--I'm not sure why its so good, but it is.  The hummus is perfect--just the right amount of lemon and garlic.  The avocado and sprouts are always nice and fresh.  The bagel's always toasted to perfection.  

Mmmm.  Hummus bagel.
author: Tsada K.

description: The first few times I went here, it was great. Then, around 4-5 years ago or so, the service went WAY downhill. I've only gone there for bagels twice in the past few years. One time I had to wait 20 mins, and the other time it took so long I just walked out after about 30 mins...ridiculous. There can be hair in the lunch items too, beware.
author: Jesse K.

description: The brunch menu is actually a little bit overwhelming. Too much choices, not necessarily stand-outs. But the space is nice, the staff is friendly and the atmosphere Lower-Haight-relaxed. You usually don't get the huge line you might find in trendier places, and that's nice.
author: Paul C.

description:
Yup, they remodeled. It looks like the place might have changed hands, too, since none of the same people work there anymore. Menu is similar, with a few new additions and a bump up of about a dollar per item. It is now very much a clone of Squat and Gobble. Meh. I liked it when it had terrible art on the walls instead of a wide-screen TV leaking sports-flavored light all over the place, but while I mourn the loss of the last cheap and uncrowded brunch spot in the Lower Haight, I bet I'll still find myself here most weekend mornings. Where else am I going to go?

Update: actually, i was wrong about the place changing hands, they just have some new faces working the counter.
author: Tom H.

description:
Less than a block from mi casa, the Grind is my 'usual' brunch spot these days. and i have no complaints about that. i have a hard time not ordering the same thing every time tho. i'm really into the Sicilian omelet. if you're veggie i am highly recommending this fabulous omelet to you. 

last time i was there the girl spent an extra long time frothing our cappuccinos, which i thought was a nice tough. foam all the way to the bottom. i meant to go back and thank her for that but i forgot. she actually seemed really excited that we ordered them too. 

i've never had to wait for a table. i like sitting outside, although one time (when i had some out of town guests along with me) there was a car alarm going off the entire time...which is no way to start your day, lemme tell ya. i can't believe people still use those things? wtf.
author: Isabel C.

description:
Finally went to The Grind Cafe for a day of work, and I was happy!  The staff are very friendly, the salads are excellent (try the pear salad with cranberries and blue cheese!).

It straddles the line between cafe and restaurant pretty well.  The wifi is kind of sketchy, but there are a few outlets you can nab for your laptop.
author: Corey C.

description:
hate this place. 

boring!  boring!  boring!

the food, coffee, service, decor JUST LIKE EVERY OTHER DAMN CAFE. somehow they managed to distill the cafe experience to it's bare essentials - which is so damn boring that i can't stand it here at the grind cafe.  starbuck's maybe commercially soulless, but this place managed to find the essence of soullessness and copy it.
author: Peter K.

description: Meh. Food wasn't anything special. Over-priced, only stopped here because we were starving. The girl that rang us up was just on the edge of being rude - a lot of attitude considering we didn't ask for anything special. I'd keep walking in either direction and find somewhere else to eat
author: Zantha S.

description:
Don't hate. Appreciate.

The Grind is what it is, and has been for years. A non-shmancy, non-sceney breakfast  joint with very basic food where groups of friends go to nurse their hangovers and laugh at each other over the previous night's shenanigans.  And I dig the fact that there are now bottles of Tabasco on each table vs two bottles for the whole restaurant placed next to the silverware. It's the little things in life that matter the most. In my case, hot sauce within reach.

3 stars.
author: Mr K.

description:
I was down in Lower Haight to watch the Seahawks game at Danny Coyle's (see that review in my profile). It occurred to me that I was about to consume a great amount of alcohol, scream my ass off at my home team, and then walk/bus back to Cow Hollow/Marina area to my bro's apt. A man needs to power up for that kind of abuse. I hadn't eaten breakfast, I hadn't had my morning coffee, and I had already had a beer. "Warrior needs food... Badly!"

Bryan B. directed me up to The Grind for a sandwich. I stood in line, then tried to joke and be friendly with the gals behind the counter, who were cute but maybe having a bad day, I dunno. They didn't crack a smile, just took my order and took my money. Whatevah.

It took a while for the order to get made. There were open tables, so it didn't seem that busy, but on the other hand I was in a hurry to get back to Danny Coyle's to see the kick off. (Which fortunately I did see, as the first 5 minutes of that Seahawks@Packers game were, as a Seahawks fan, the best part of the game. Argh. Next year.) So... I stood and watched poker on their flat screen (yeah, no playoff game. It's THAT kind of place).

the sandwich was pretty tasty. The fries were ok, but they stuck a pickle into the box which dripped all over the fries. I gotta say, pickle juice on french fries is fucking gross. It makes the fries taste like they were rotten. I wound up spitting up into my water which really sucked. I like to conserve water. At least it wasn't into my beer, as I like to conserve beer more.

So... I drop a star for the unfriendliness of the lady behind the counter, and for mixing pickle juice with french fries, and another for cost. But the sandwich was pretty good.
author: Will L.

description:
It's only a couple blocks from my place, but really never go out of my way to swing by The Grind.  My tastes run more toward Bean There for coffee and Kate's Kitchen or Squat & Gobble for breakfast fare.  I've never had a bad experience here, and if I didn't have my other favorites I'd go by more.

OH, they do have that really strong ginger ale that brings a tear to me eye!
author: Eric E.

description:
My wife and I decided to take off on our scooter and find a new spot in the city that we had never been.  we ended up in the lower haight and happened upon this place.  

it's a happening little spot with lots of light, big sliding windows allowing for lots of air, and outside seating which was a plus.  we had lunch (i had the crispy chicken sandwich and fries) which was very tasty and she had the chicken cheesesteak (even better!)  it was a very enjoyable, relaxing lunch with plenty of great people watching.
author: Matt S.

description: This place Is my favorite cafe within miles.  The price is fair, the portions are pretty large and the food is delicious.  The variety is great too for lunch and breakfast which is available all day.  The French dip is awesome and I have a hard time wanting to get anything else but every time I get something different I love that too.  All the breakfasts are really good and they have hash browns which seems more and more rare in this era of breakfast potatoes.  The spud variety is pretty great, they  even have curly fries.  Yay.  I also really like the poppy seed dressing with the side salad which is really fresh and crisp.  Oh and I love that there juice and smoothies come in a big pint glass.   I just had their crispy chicken sandwich w avocado bacon and cheddar which was kind of blew me away.  My only complaint is they use chicken strips instead of a whole crispy chicken breast but they got the flavor spot on.
author: Ian S.

description:
Finally, a place on Haight that isn't overpriced. This place is such a great breakfast/ brunch spot. You walk in, order your food and find a place to sit. The prices are very reasonable and so are the portions. I had the pastrami sandwich with fries & a coffee for 8.25, he had the corned beef hash for 8.75 - we both enjoyed our food and felt just right after - stuffed but not too stuffed. 

It was packed for Sunday brunch, but it seemed no one had a hard time finding a place to sit right away. If it wasn't cold and rainy, I would've opted for the nice outdoor seating area. Downside: they charge for drink refills, but that won't stop me from making another visit.
author: Melissa P.

description:
The place is more or less a weekend morning institution for me.  I meet there one morning per week with an old friend and catch up on the events of the week.

One thing that used to irritate me about the place was the bad art and the bad service.  If you wanted al fresco, you had to strain to hear your name yelled by one of the surly cooks behind the counter, then weave your way to the rear of the business and pick up your order.  This could be quite the adventure when the place is busy.

No more since they redesigned the place.  Along with the new look is better cooking and a much better attitude.  There is one waitress who is a Melody Soprano look-alike and she is augmented by a blonde who works during the week.  The blonde is a jaw dropping, stop, stare and stammer beauty.  Not that I notice since I am taken and everything.

The menu has not changed much since the bad old days but there is much greater attention to detail.  There is now table service.  The omelets and scrambles are piping hot and everything seems fresh.  It used to be that you had to come in before nine AM on the weekends to beat the influx of Castro interior designers who would take over the place at ten or so.  May I use your chair?  Would you mind scooting over your table?  We have ten more members of the Velvet Mafia coming in, why don't you eat outside?  I think those guys have moved back to Kate's Kitchen.
author: Cheezy P.

description:
I only live a few doors down on Haight Street from The Grind. It is my go-to breakfast joint. But I hafta say, when its crowded in there, the service drops off considerably and I'm left waiting for eggs for 30 minutes. The boys in the kitchen area do indeed work their asses off though. I give them that credit. And I'm not really sure how to solve the waiting time because the kitchen doesn't look big enough for a couple extra prep cooks. Any breakfast joint has a bit of a wait on the weekends. I guess the only alternative is to not go during brunch time. Maybe its my elitist "i only live 3 doors down i should'nt have to wait for this shit" attitude that I need to flip. Hehe.

The food IS decent. But I feel like 7 times out of ten my order is missing some ingredient like avocado, or the cheese in my omelette is barely melted; its the little things that add up, you know? I know they're in a rush to complete the order but hey, I pay attention to avocado. That's why I order it. And I hate being "THAT" guy that complains to a busy waitress running around bringing people their scrambles.

The remodel they did before the New Year was MUCH NEEDED. It looks like a fresh establishment. The girls that work the counter are all cute and adorable.  

I will still continue to go here for breakfast and to meet up with folks before facing the weekend. But I'm knocking them 2 stars for having customer satisfaction issues. I just feel like for as busy as the place gets (and seriously there are lines out the door sometimes and every seat is packed!) they could be a bit more efficient. They should WANT to be more efficient to get more customers taken care of.
author: Matthew M.

description:
The food in general doesn't particularly stand out, but I can always count on the Haight scram with wheat toast and fruit instead of potatoes for a good start to the day, and I'm quite fond of the chicken pesto sandwich.

The staff are what earn the place a fourth star. I'm a local regular, and I eat at the place 5-8 times a week. The cute girls and pleasant guys know my coffee order and often begin preparing it before I make it to the counter. They go out of their way to be nice to me, and they've earned my loyalty.
author: Brian M.

description: Cafe nestled in the heart of the Lower Haight. Had their Lox sandwich and a double Cappuccino. Neither was particularly noteworthy. Space wasn't very nice and the featured local art was bad. If I were in the area again, I'd stick to my old standby: Squat & Gobble.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Okay coffee - nice to pick up when you are so hungover you want to bury yourself alive.  Like right now.

EDIT April 2007:

I hate The Grind for personal reasons. Getting coffee there was basically one of those weird "this is the first day of the rest of your life" kind of moments and I will forever associate it with kicking off the shittiest two months of my very short life.  However, they are the closest place to my apt that take credit cards, serve food and have wi-fi that is not Squat & Gobble (a place I've vowed to never give another fucking dime to), so I've returned a few times to abuse the wi-fi and have my solitary weekend brunches w/ my macbook. And what do you know? the cooked food is totally decent.  3 stars.

People complaining about how it is too "clean" for the neighborhood should perhaps acquaint themselves with Craigslist apartment ads for this neighborhood and see just how "cheap" it is to live in this part of the Lower Haight.
author: Maria D.

description:
I like this place.  I tripped into it while waiting for Cinzia's very first ever ballet recital last weekend.  I rate it only on the damn good latte I sipped and the look of sheer joy on Reno's face as he  massacred one of their huge m+m cookies.   i really wanted to eat dinner here... the menu has, umm everything, but my timing was just off.  

the service was great, super friendly, fast.
author: Meg W.

description:
I totally forgot about yelping here since I came here in June and it was worth the random drive my friend and i took.

My friend and I happen to spot this place after finding out the Joe's pot o' Soul was supposed to be open but they weren't. We drove around to find a good breakfast/brunch spot to dine at and my friend passes by a couple places then says "Hey, what about there?" and points to the Grind Cafe. I said sure why not. We easily found parking and walked over. 

When we walked in i looked up and noticed the huge chalkboard menu. LOTS of food and snacks and drinks to choose from, definite worth 2 stars. For the variety they had everything was very well-priced (under $10 a pop except for the steak and eggs, duh) I ordered the Lower Haight omelet since the ingredients caught my eyes (chicken apple sausage, spinach, sun dried tomatoes, and feta... YUMMMM) and I can't remember what my friend had but he did have a fresh squeezed orange juice. 

The atmosphere was real nice; busy in the kitchen but very casual in the dining area. The cashier was friendly and made sure she had got our orders right. I'd like to come back here again for sure. I only give it 4 stars since I am a fan now but would like to come here more often to experience the full force of their menu :)
author: Marie G.

description:
I love the makeover! It's so nice and clean now. I don't have to feel ashamed to bring my mother-in-law here anymore. Some of the food is great and some is mediocre. For instance, their hash browns, scrambled eggs and toast are so-so, but their waffles and pancakes are delicious. I've had just about everything on the breakfast menu and most of it is pretty decent. This is a very typical breakfast place. You can't really order veggie-meat products here as in other breakfast joints. It has a nice front patio for warm days but it doesn't get much sunlight. There is never a line out the door and the food is prepared pretty quickly. This is a good place to bring a laptop and sit around for hours while sipping coffee.

Let me describe some of the best food I've had there:

Strawberry Waffle: 
One large waffle the size of a dinner plate, that was about 1" thick, with tons of fresh strawberries all over and sprinkled with powdered sugar. 

Home-fry Mound (I think they changed it to the Hash Mound): 
A large mound of potatoes smothered in melted cheddar, green onions, black olives, huge slabs of avocado and a dollop of sour cream. Very filling.

I think that with the makeover they made some changes I don't necessarily like all that much. I used to get fresh-squeezed grapefruit juice and they would squeeze it in front of me but now they serve it from a pitcher. The last time I had it it tasted pretty bad... like it was fermented.

Overall though, I give it a four because it's clean, has a patio, is close to home, the food is pretty good, they prepare it quickly, there is no line, and they offer many meal choices but most of all, their coffee doesn't suck.
author: L. L.

description: This place is a solid option for grabbing a sandwich or salad with a friend. There was a long line, but it moved quickly. The staff was friendly and overall it was a great experience. The salad took almost 30 minutes to come out, which was annoying. I will go back.
author: Shanna T.

description:
Hey, people--you're at a coffee shop. With outdoor seating. That makes KILLER espresso drinks. Has pastries to DIE for. A reasonably priced menu. A great atmosphere. Plenty of room for the stroller set. Yet hip enough for the rest of us. Perfect location. Friendly, zany staff. 

And you're complaining because your chicken fried steak was disappointing? Go to Max's for chicken fried steak. Why are you ordering CFS at a coffee shop, anyway?

Re rude staff, never while I've been there, but I'm sure it happens, and when it does it definitely "kills the vibe."
author: Cate F.

description:
I know people have had some not so great expieriences at this place.
However, EVERYTIME i have eaten here its been great!

I always get the BLTA (a basic blt with avavado) on a bageutte...with a side salad...mmm....mmmm...mmmm...its so good!!

And the iced tea is refreshing and a good size! 

So...if you eat at the Grind and want something safe and DELICIOUS get the BLTA sandwich!!
author: Keila E.

description:
I've been going here for years. Why? The BLTA. 
Sadly, I've watched the price of this beautiful sandwich (work-of-art) rise drastically over the years. 

BLTA = $8.25? Ouch! 

But I just love it. Gotta spoil myself once in a while.
author: Ayy C.

description: Solid cup of coffee...and if you ever need the WAP key, just punch in Grind's phone number.
author: Jimmie S.

description:
The Grind is right around the corner from my house but I didn't start going there until about a year ago when my son and his fiance visited. What's that old saying? "People can go to Paris or Rome but they don't even know what's in their own backyard". That's not a saying? Well, mark me down for that one.
I've had several breakfasts there, once, the fruit/yogurt bowl which was
very filling, another time I've had their eggs, bacon and toast. Filling but nothing special. But I absolutely LOVE the burgers. They come with really nice green leaf lettuce, RIPE tomatos, pickles and they cook it up to your specs. I get the salad as a side and, while they use a lot of ribs from the lettuces and are a bit scanty on the croutons, it's still a hell of an improvement from the salads I had in the South.
It's packed on the weekends so I don't go but on a Wed. afternoon it's nice and mellow. I love to people watch and there was a very pretty woman holding the cutest puppy inside. Brought out the neighborhood feel seeing that. The staff are superb and friendly and the prices are inexpensive. Nice place to go on foggy afternoons!
author: michael s.

description:
I don't think I expect much from brunch places - decent eggs, good hot sauce, great coffee and a relaxed atmosphere to start off a Saturday morning. 

Discovered the Grind and it didn't quite make the cut. The staff is friendly enough however the coffee is uninspired. I also seem destined to never get a croissant when I want a breakfast sandwish - interestingly, they are never, and I mean never, out of english muffins (how many times can you use the word never in a sentence?). This was also true at the Grind but a worthwhile substiution to sourdough was made.  The hash browns are also good. 

Sadly, the grind, like many brunch locations feels the need to optimize their space by seating 40 odd people in a space that should only take about 30-35. Bottom line: you're going to be very close to your neighboring table. As much as I like other people, I don't like them that much.,
author: Abhi S.

description: Great place for a variety of solid breakfast plates, sandwiches and salads. The tuna melt rocks.
author: Jeff T.

description:
Noisiest coffee shop in the world.

It's like they are trying to drive people out - in the mornings heavy metal and drum and bass so loud that everyone needs to shout over it and in the afternoons when they are closing up they bang around in the kitchen so that you leave.

Perhaps the staff like to get home early and minimize customers....
author: liam B.

description:
This may very well be my favorite place in the city (at least for now). I take my friends here for breakfast/brunch because of the vast selection of good food and the friendly atmosphere. Sometimes I'll just visit to have coffee and sit on the patio and work on the computer.

Definitely that "good breakfast place" in the area.
author: Eric F.

description:
I'm running an experiment right now. I'm writing my review FROM the restaurant! Blackberries are handy.

The Grind is the kind of place I miss having in LA. Urth Caffe attempts but is a little high concept. I guess Vivienne's is closest to the mark. I should go back there soon... But I digress. I'm sure the Northern Californians reading this don't care about LA breakfast spots.

The grind is a triple threat. The food is awesome, the prices are right, and the atmosphere is delightful. Though to be fair, that last part might just be a symptom of the city. I love San Francisco! Again, I digress. Maybe this reviewing-on-the-go idea isn't the goods.

It's worth noting that the home fries are top shelf.  They alone would have been worth draggng myself out of bed on a coveted day off.  And I didn't indulge at 10 in the morning, but $2.50 beers during happy hour score bonus points.
author: Mike T.

description: This place is right around the corner, so I've been here quite a few times. Their food is decent. But lately they have been SLOWWWW and messing up our orders - this has happened on multiple occasions. Just today we went and my husband's lunch arrived 20-25 minutes after mine. We vowed that this was the last time we'll go here since I often leave pissed off. Too bad, because I like their curly fries and their outdoor seating. If they had just said something like, 'Sorry your order is taking so long - can I offer you a free soda or cookie?' I wouldn't be as peeved, but they just smiled like it was business as usual.  Grrrrr....ind.
author: Lulu P.

description:
The coffee is gross. The people are unfriendly. The service is bad.

It's just their outdoor seating and unfortunate convenient location to me that saves them. Sometimes I am just too damn lazy to walk any further for a juice and a bagel. And if it's nice out, it's hard to find a place to enjoy the outdoors with your meal, and they do have a prime people-watching location. 

But otherwise, I try really really hard to avoid them and walk the extra block to go to the always-reliable Katz or Squat & Gobble.
author: Nina H.

description: The food was okay. The internet was free. The water was delightful. The place was kinda cool on a Monday afternoon.
author: Blu M.

description:
I really really really want to love this place.  I kind of do.  OK, that's not true.  

Have you ever dated a girl who was absolutely beautiful but who annoyed you nonetheless?  No, her beauty didn't annoy you, and it was natural, not a put-on or an example of masterful makeup artistry or a figment of your own delusionally hopeful imagination, but there just wasn't much else going on.  She could be smart and maybe even intelligent, but she wasn't quick on the uptake, or at least she didn't pick up on all the little cues that she should pick up on.  Those cues that you picked up on with her.  And maybe you enjoyed each other's company, but when you weren't physically together, you wondered whether you were just wasting your time with her?  And you had your breakup speech all planned out and maybe even rehearsed; you had chosen a coffeehouse or a park that you had never been to together so that neither of your memories or daily routines would be ruined by this ultimately trivial but nonetheless life-changing event?  But then when you saw her crossing the street in her cheap pink flip-flops or leaning down to pick a dandelion from the grass--and her hair would fall just so--you couldn't go through with it.  You just had to continue to be with this girl because she was beautiful, right?  Just really naturally pretty.  Someone no one in his right mind would give up.  Not without good reason?

Well, that girlfriend is The Grind Cafe.  It's gorgeous, and the menu is really promising.  The atmosphere is even pleasant, and this is an accomplishment in the Lower Haight.  But the food is just so bland.  It's not bad, and it's presented really beautifully, but on your walk home, you always find yourself wondering whether you should start spending less time here and more time at a grungier-looking restaurant that understands your needs better.

But hell, I'm a sucker for a pretty face, so I'll keep enjoying The Grind's mound of hash browns and a sunny-side-up egg.  Wouldn't you?
author: John S.

description: The banana walnut pancakes are yummy.  Nice and friendly cashier.  It is a nice place to hang out over coffee and/or beers and read.  I like the outdoor seating.
author: J M.

description:
The grind has gone downhill in recent years.  I went there again today and it just confirmed my suspicion.  Bland, overpriced food.  The kicker?  There was a group of probably drunk girls next to our table who let their dog walk all over the table and drink from their cups.  No one from the grind said anything to them.  Really appetizing.  I saw a brilliant bumper sticker recently:  "Dog people are the new crazy cat ladies."  Couldn't agree more.

Update (5/28/09)

I am taking away an additional star because against my better instincts, I recently went there again.  It reinforced my reinforced my negative opinions of this place.  Overpriced, rude staff, too crowded (why it's always so packed, I'll never understand), bugs flying around.  Skanky, and not in a good way.
author: Jesse K.

description: This places is pretty good, mostly for the atmosphere.  Nice granola-y but clean coffee shop with outdoor seating.  Fun to sit at their sidewalk tables and people watch.  Their food is also really good.  I usually get a grilled cheese but the last time I went I got the home fries with cheese, avacado, etc.  The good thing is that they let customers sit and read/study or chat for a couple hours and don't kick you out after you've eaten.  Prices are moderate- about $7.50 for a grilled cheese and fries.  Whenever I am in the neighborhood, I like to stop in!
author: Sarah Y.

description:
standard fare for coffee and breakfast.

just simple, decent, good, food.
author: I Be E.

description: My roommate and I love coming here whether it be for a quick coffee or Saturday/Sunday brunch. It can get pretty crowded on the weekends, but we have never had trouble finding a table. The staff is so nice and personable, they really make you feel at home!
author: Ashley B.

description:
This place recently upgraded their entire restaurant. Since then it has become one of the worst places to eat in town.

1. The service is really bad, you end up waiting 30 minutes or more for your food, while other people who come in later than you get it first. This has happened to me more than 3 times.

2. They took down all the artwork and just have a TV.

3. They removed the community bulletin board and replaced it with a TV that just shows ads by big companies.

4. They use disposable cups rather than cups that can be washed.

5. The food is just average. You can get the same food at Eddies for half the price and just 4 blocks away.

This used to be a great place but I just won't go back anymore. They lost all their charm and they no longer support the community. It is like a fashion model who looks great on the outside but is really screwed up on the inside. All this place cares about is making a buck.
author: Chris R.

description:
Fantastic in every way. I love this place and have been coming here since the day they opened. The owners mom comes in still and makes the dressings for all the salad from scratch. Try the poppy seed dressing it's off the hook. 

Great breakfast and salads. I can't eat the lasagna because it has mushrooms and I am allergic to them but my friends tell me it is great. This is another place I come back to all the time.
author: don h.

description:
The Grind is not exactly what I expected when a friend of mine suggested we have brunch in the Lower Haight. I was stoked for the idea of a divey, nasty, greasy spoon with an assertive, short-tempered wait staff that had been working there for a decade.

So I approach the place from the west, slowly, sizing it up; looks alright, so far. I see hipsters and students and art kids smoking on the patio. This is usually a good sign, at least for my tastes and general comfort level.

Once inside, however, surprise! Exposed duct work, track lighting and the ubiquitous gigantic fucking chalk board menu. The offerings looked good, though, so I chose to forgive them and let bygones be bygones while some coked out dude started yammering at my friend.

I ordered the two eggs, scram, with hash and subbed an English muffin  for the toast. I also split a short stack with my friend. For a drink, "Orange juice, and lots of it, please." The wait staff was perky, chipper and did not at all look amused... or hungover. This was a problem.

But the food was good. Really good, actually, and the short stack reminded me of home, so damn that's gotta be worth at least one star... and the eggs were yummy and there was ample hot sauce at the table (although just Tabasco... when will people get it right? ANYTHING but Tabasco!), and pretty soon I was happy and full, and I didn't have to give up 30 minutes sitting on the curb waiting for a table (that's you, Porkstore... that's what you sound like).

So, damnit, a reluctant 3... but well earned. Even if it did feel like Hayes Valley in there.
author: Aiden B.

description:
The grind has a really nice, low key atmosphere.
There's free wireless, and good assortment of beverages which makes it easy to sit back and chill there.

For the food, my roommate and I have had breakfast once a week there for over a year, and we love the food.  It's a little more expensive than other breakfast places, but it comes out very quick, and the staff is mega nice with great customer service.
author: C B.

description:
Straight up, I agree with the "too small of water cups" criticism. Room temp water served in tiny cups is the hungover kid's worst breakfast-nightmare.  Luckily, the 2 mornings I've been here I was fresh as a peach. 

Minus 1 star for the pricey menu, but the omelets are the bomb dot com.
author: Nikki H.

description: This place is awesome.  If you have a bad experience then go back again and try something else.  They are so fast even when the line is out the door which is a tell tale sign that this place is doing things right.   I typically go here for breakfast which is always cooked to perfection.  I look for consistency in the places I eat and The Grind never fails.  Try the grind combo for the big man in all of us.  If you give them a bad review because you don't like the hamburger you got then try something else before giving them 2 stars.  Also the grind is about a million times better than any Crepeville baloney.
author: Mister L.

description: Since moving to the neighborhood The Grind has been one of my staples - for wifi before I had mine installed, for coffee, for breakfast, for lunch, dinner and even a glass of wine when needed.  The Grind has it all, reasonable prices, great staff, good music.  I am a BIG fan.
author: Whitney P.

description: I like this place. The food is fresh, the staff is nice, and the place is in a good location. What more would you like? I ordered a spinach omelette with bacon and avocado. Delicious! The staff was nice; very attentive.
author: Miss P.

description:
Amanda Says: 
Here's what I am wondering: How is it possible for food to taste like nothing? 

David Says: 
Well, the hash browns were edible--after I covered them in ketchup

Consensus: The Grind is The Gross. The food was cold and the tofu scramble was a sorry mess. If you are into "chalkboard restaurants" and live in the lower haight head on down to the Squat and Gobble. The house potatoes are at least edible and the Gobble knows a thing or two about tofu scramble.
author: AmanDave H.

description:
Meh...

Not a fan and vegans beware.  I had the tofu scramble which was basically tofu rectangles tossed around with crappy canned mushrooms, tasteless avocados and lackluster tomatoes.  Super mediocre food.

I love outdoor seating but this outdoor seating made me feel like I was in a college town sitting outside the student union.  Bad lighting inside for sure.  Lame and sterile atmosphere.  

In a city this beautiful with great food and great ambiance please don't settle for mediocre.
author: Monica H.

description: I'm reading some of these reviews and they are ridiculous. I live down the street and come to the Grind at least once or twice a week. The breakfast items are great. The breakfast burrito and grind combo are my favorites. So good I have to stop myself from going there more. Here's the deal, it's a very good place to grab food, be it brunch, a burger, a salad...whatever. Since the remodel, it appears that their kitchen capacity has improved dramatically too. The complaints I'm seeing on here about "poor service" and "inefficiencies" are baffling to me. Common Sense. If there is a line out the door, all the tables look full, and there are people waiting for to go orders....It's gonna take a while to get your food on a Saturday or Sunday morning. You are talking about a very clean place with above average, fairly priced food in very popular part of SF. There are too many bad ones to count. This isn't the place you go "to brunch." It's where you go because you don't want to deal with the bs that is "brunching"  but want the same or similar quality food. Having been here too many times to count, I have to say it's got to be the most consistent place in the Lower Haight. Can't wait to go back again!
author: Paul Z.

description:
I like to call this "MTV's The Grind with Eric Nies". 

I could eat the Haight Scram with tofu instead of eggs everyday! Their toast is perfect with it- big slices of sourdough.
author: Heidi J.

description: This is my go-to local brunch place.  It has a standard brunch menu that includes croissant french toast.  Lots of people sit in the outdoor area with there dogs so I like taking my golden retriever here for brunches.  Sometimes the food comes out a little slowly or they mess up your order a little or the line is a little long but nothing too dramatic has ever happened to me.  Good standard brunch place.
author: barbara b.

description:
Nice neighborhood cafe with awesome outdoor seating. 

They have an extensive menu with lots of breakfast options: eggs, omelets, pancakes, french toast, waffles, bagels and smoothies. They also have a variety of salads, sandwiches and burgers. 

I came here on a lazy Sunday and enjoyed a veggie delight salad - filled with tomato, cucumber, sprouts, avocado, egg, kidney & garbanzo beans. 

I thought the ordering process was a bit disorganized - the first girl only took drink orders and the cash rep took food orders and it seemed to cause some confusions. The wait in line was long, but the food came fairly quick. 

It was nice to hang out with a friend and enjoy a quick bite - I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Gladys C.

description:
I like this place a lot.
Lots of vegetarian oprions, I feel comfortable sitting here for hours with friends.
Nice atmosphere too.  My husband had to wait an hour for his food on a Sunday at noon, it was very busy though.
author: rani s.

description:
Is it dirty?  Yes!  is it a little overpriced?  Maybe.  I think the place is a better bargain that Squat and Gobble, but S &G has a much better atmosphere.  Why are you going out to eat - food quality or aesthetics?

I usually get a half salad/sandwich option, and that runs about 7 bucks.  Par for the course in the city, me thinks.

Now, here's the think I always take away as my Grind image- there are these strange little fruit flies which inhabit many establishments in the city and are really hard to kill.  They fly around lazily, but if you try and swat them, they move really fast.  The Grind always has about 10 of these suckers flying around.  I don't mind them so much, but I can understand why YOU would...
author: Andrew C.

description:
I go to this coffee shop almost every day. Staff is nice and accommodating. The food needs a bit more FLAVOR, but I recommend the chicken fried steak, french dip, and salads. WIFI and nice staff makes it worth while. 
As for the look, I agree with what another person wrote about it having a Southern Louisiana look to it. I like it because I happen to be from New Orleans! Les se le bon temp roule Grind!
author: Vanessa M.

description:
Decided to give the recently remodeled The Grind Cafe a try for lunch last Wednesday. Popped in and checked out the menu. I had been thinking I might get a burger, as they use Niman Ranch beef. But then I noticed a "Crispy Chicken" sandwich on the menu. Described as a fried chicken breast on a bun with lettuce and mayo. $7.50 with fries.

I grabbed a seat and as I waited noticed that they've nicely modernized the cafe's decor. Finally my food was ready and I walked it over to Duboce Park to enjoy in the sunshine.

I was disappointed to find that the chicken sandwich consisted not of a single fried chicken breat, but 3 limply fried, generic, previously frozen chicken fingers. I took a bite hoping to find something worth liking, but the chicken fingers weren't even adequately fried They weren't raw, just not very golden. Limp and pale. Bleh. I ate a few fries which were ok, but decided to ditch the entire meal.

Grabbed a burger at Burger Joint down the street. It's not the greatest burger, but at least I knew what I was getting and it's tastey enough.

I can't vouch for any of the other food at The Grind Cafe, but I definitely wouldn't recommend the crispy chicken sandwich. I'd like to like this place. Especially since it's so close. If anyone has any specific recommendations for this place I'd be interested to here.
author: Brian J.

description:
We love eating brunch in their outdoor cave, even on cold days.  The food is pretty good and the same cute girl is always working the register.  They sometimes charge us extra for stuff but we don't mind. 

As a hangover go-to, it works magic, supplying pretty much what you expect your order to taste like, and giving you an environment that's clean and understated without feeling like a cafeteria or a mcdonalds. Somebody take your shirt off in here. Show your titties!
author: Abby M.

description:
Not a bad place...

the pluses: good sandwiches, good veggie selection (they have both Garden Burgers AND Boca Burgers), eggs and omelets.  Free WiFi!  Good to work in, they won't kick you out.

the minuses: a little pricey for food.  Also, very echoey due to lack of wall hangings, carpet, or anything soft.  All tables are veneer "wood" and the place is a little chilly.
author: Brian D.

description: New favorite go-to brunch spot. The food is fresh, the service reasonably efficient (though the order takers don't always seem interested in life or eye contact at all). You can also substitute stuff, which is good, and nice mimosas. Occasional douche-bags who sit inside while their dog barks outside annoying everyone outside, but otherwise fairly chill crowd. On the verge of boredom with it, but at least you don't have to wait outside for 10 minutes to get seated.
author: Mi M.

description: Neighborhood feel, friendly staff, and available internet (just don't be a jerk and sit here for hours without buying food, and avoid peak dining times).
author: Eric M.

description: This place was good back in the day but man their food quality has dropped so bad the last few years. The food here is hit or miss and that can really kill your appetite. You really have be lucky if the right chef is there on the day you dine to have a ok dining experience. I dont dine here no more because the food just does not taste good anymore
author: Art N.

description: Aaaaaah the grind, one of my favorite neighborhood haunts. The French burger with skinny fries lightly toasted on a French bread.......yum!!! Pair that with a sweet chai latte and I'm then ready for my post grind nap....best burger eva!!!
author: Kirsty E.

description: My friends and I stopped in to get out of the rain and grab some hot drinks and this place was spot on.  The service was good, and quick and the food looked awesome.  We had already ate before stopping in but we made the mistake of sitting under the big breakfast menu and I seriously wanted to eat my damn hand off reading that thing.  Everything on the menu sounded so good.  I had a hot chocolate which was creamy, hot and sweet and hit the spot perfectly :-)
author: JiujitsuGrinds X.

description: Veggie salad is great!  Spring mix, romaine, garbanzo beans, avocado, tomatoes, sprouts and cucumber.  $7.25.  Brett's Niman ranch beef steak and egg with hash brown was $10.25.  I just moved to this neighborhood and intrigued that food costs less in the Lower Haight.
author: Wakako U.

description: What is there to say about The Grind Cafe...besides that it is absolutely delicious! You know that feeling you get when you wake up late Saturday morning and you want that ultimate meal? It's the time where it's to late for breakfast but your just not ready for lunch. That is what I call "The Grind Time." The fellas and I typically roll into here like a scene out of Entourage (Aw Yeah!) with our eyes on the prize. For me that prize is the Haight Scram. All the scrambles hit the spot. You can get it with just about anything and ranging from bacon, apple sausage, lox, Niemen ranch beef, or veggies (for the health conscious). I'm sure lunch is delightful, but why ruin a good thing when breakfast is what I want.
author: Adam S.

description:
The go-to brunch/lunch place for us in our 'hood.  If the weather's nice we can sit outside and bring the dog, and rarely are we there at times when it's too crowded to find a table inside.  Behind the counter they know us as regulars and always greet us with a smile and small talk.  

The food is yummy and reasonably priced, and the portions are big enough that I can share with my toddler and still feel like I had a meal.  

A great place to meet friends (as has been said already) or go with the family -- all around, an enjoyable experience!
author: Brian H.

description:
The street-front patio has lovely ambience when the weather is nice, and the interior is bright, airy, and inviting. It's a shame that The Grind fails so horribly in its main purpose, which is food and coffee. In fact, the ambience alone earns it the second star in this review.

I bought the tofu scramble* and was amazed to discover that in this day and age, in San Francisco, California, there are still cooks who believe that diners enjoy a hefty pile of plain, unseasoned tofu. Or that anybody who would eat tofu must have been tragically separated from their taste buds in a horrific accident. I poured salt, Tapatio, Tabasco, and ketchup all over that sad, blindingly white mess and I still could not eat half the serving. Damn, at least toss a pity-splash of soy sauce on it while you cook it!

*(Don't write off this review out of hand because I'm some tofu-eating hippy loser. A restaurant should strive to hold all their offerings up to the same high standard, regardless of whether they're the chef's personal favorites or not.)

I was meeting with folks there and had to stay a while after I finished eating, so I foolishly thought I couldn't go wrong with ordering a coffee. I'm just going to put it all out there: either their coffee roaster is dying a slow, horrible death right now, or they just plain hate their customers. There, I said it. I don't know a ton about coffee roasting but I suspect it wasn't roasted nearly enough- the taste was watery, burnt, and painfully tart. I could hardly drink two ounces of a twelve-ounce cup. And I. LOVE. COFFEE.

Bad news.
author: Erika L.

description:
I went here for the first time, eventhough I've lived in (upper) haight for the the past 5 years!  

The service----seemed very good to me, and easy to order menu.  Lots of Ketchup/condiments for your pleasures!
The food----Pretty good.  No greasy omelette's like the squat and pay us $10 for potatoes!  I had a Mediterranean scramble and it was pretty good. It's not gourmet, but it was $7.50!  
The Coffee----Well, I'm an f'ing coffee snob, so i thought it was 'burnt.'  That's usually a case of the machine making the coffee combined with crappy beans!  I have to give their espresso drinks a shot?

Overall, a good place to grab some breakfast, sit outside , freakin' chill people it's just a cafe in the haight!
author: Mark K.

description:
I would say food slightly not as good as Kate's Kitchen but ambiance a lot better.  Portions are pretty nice.  I love all the skylights.  

FYI, The orange juice is fresh squeezed, but not by them.
author: Kurosh H.

description: Had breakfast here yesterday, I'm always weary about scrambled eggs but decided to get The Grind Scram. I really liked the way they make their scramble, lots of filling and I like the way it's all packed in this rectangle shape with cheese on top holding it together. I like dense tasting texture and that's what this scramble was! Very happy. The Hashbrown I got was ok not the best I've had. They need to make it more crispy on the outside, but it was good. Coffee, eh, kinda watery.
author: Karen T.

description: Bun...Cheese....Meat....Bun....ahhh...Heaven...no need for condiments...order from the kid's menu...substitute the fries with a salad...have the dressing on the side...pick honey mustard...I heart this place!!!!!
author: Persimmon W.

description: Love the staff! So friendly and they sure do know their coffee and big eats! Want a belly-full of food and laughs? Go to The Grind any DAY! Say hello to Ashley, Andrea, Valicia, Kelly, Nicole and Angela (the newbie). They love to make friends and make you full! :) Yummy lattes and frothy caps!
author: Ashley F.

description: I started coming to The Grind shortly after moving to Lower Haight, and it has become my absolute favorite - I come here several times a week. Consistently great service, friendly staff and an awesome menu. I can't recommend it enough!
author: Molly E.

description:
I actually like it here and if I lived in San Francisco, I'd probably go often to just eat a late breakfast or lunch and do some work, read a book, just be anti-social and  chill or people watch. Oh, there's free wireless. 

There are few sit-down places to eat that I feel comfortable going alone but the food is good enough, the portions are nice. The lighting is good. The girls that work there are friendly. 

It seemed like the food took a weeeee bit long to come and a weeeee bit pricey for basic choices but I won't complain. No fanfare, just solid and reliable.
author: Aushlee C.

description: Came here on a Sunday morning for some breakfast and it was so damn tasty (can't go wrong with the breakfast burrito with a side of hash browns).  The service was friendly, the coffee was delicious, and its a very relaxed atmosphere.  Will certainly be back soon.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
I like the grind. For so long I've walked past it and wanted to go in because of their outside patio, because of the name (grind is such a cool word), because of the decor. I just never did. 

Now I have, a number of times. 

The drip coffee (I had today) is what you'd expect from a drop coffee (i.e. it could be bad, but it is a decent coffee!). The latte's are pretty good, nice glass, nice consistency :) I was a lil let down by the flavour because I had a soy latte (i'm lactose intolerant) and I don't like the taste of soy milk. Next time I'm in I'll suffer the pain of a real milk latte!

So far the thing i've been most impressed with is the food and the size of the portions. Seeing other people's portions make me realize the huge/tasty salad that I shared with someone is actually their defacto when it comes to portion size. The price of which was completely humbling. 

Places like the grind make me sad that I do not live closer to Haight!
author: mike o.

description: We were there on Saturday for a late lunch. The cafe was almost full but the atmosphere was very pleasant. The service was good. We had the French Dip and it was tasty.
author: Julie G.

description: Great neighborhood, Great coffee, Good breakfast. What I really loved were the baristas. It is a counter place, one where you order get a number and they bring the food to your table, but I just kept wanting to get up and order more and pick the baristas brains. They were really friendly and had great recommendations for lunch spots. We took their word and were extremely pleased. Good starting point for our getaway in the City.
author: Nathaniel M.

description: Standard breakfast & lunch fare.  Good selection of sandwiches, omelets, scrambles and other breakfast items (french toast, granola).  Especially nice on a warm day when you can sit out in the front patio and soak in the rays.
author: F. P.

description: So I ALMOST gave this place 5 stars because they have the BEST peanut butter and banana bagel in the entire universe.  Seriously.  That's what I get every time I go there.  A damn peanut butter and banana bagel.  On a wheat bagel.  Or when they're out of wheat bagels, then a cinnamon one.  They toast the bagel, glob HUGE amounts of peanut butter on that bad boy, and then place thinly sliced bananas on there.  Yes, people.  It's a work of art!  Actually I don't care how it looks just as long as it makes the happy place in my tummy dance.  And that it does, every time!  But to provide my yummy bagel with company, I usually pair it with a caramel latte.  OMFG.  I'll say it again: OMFG!!!!!  BEST CARAMEL LATTE EVER!!!!!!!!!  Starbucks, who?  Coffee Bean, what?!  No longer.  It is ALL about the caramel latte.  It's nice and sweet, but not too sweet.  Very creamy.  Sure my stomach is rumbling an hour after I finish it, but chalk that up to my lactose intolerance.  Yes.  I will suffer the effects of bloating and stomach gurgling to indulge in this latte.  Soooo worth it.  But one day I switched it up and ordered their mango smoothie.  I just KNEW it was gonna be good since it took them, like, 5 minutes to make.  And there's nothing more annoying then getting a smoothie that melts while it's in your hands or you can drink in its entirety in 3 minutes.  My first suck from the straw produced a frown and various veins bulging from my forehead.  This smoothie was THICK and JUICY and SWEET and good!  I'm big on drink-to-food ratio so this accompanied my bagel perfectly.  I don't know why I've never had lunch there.  I mean I actually go during lunch and just opt for my bagel.  But if it's any consolation, I've gone with friends who have the audacity to order lunch during lunchtime and it always looks scrumptious.  I feel like I should give 5 stars alone for just the damn bagel, latte, and smoothie.  I mean if a restaurant is making me convulse with those random things then how much more for an actual meal?!  Contrary to other yelpers, I've never had a run in with a snooty cashier or anything like that, thank God.  I'm not one to hold my tongue if someone is giving me attitude for no damn reason.  The service has always been great, albeit a tad slow.  But other than that, I love this place.  It also seems like a great neighborhood hangout with locals.
author: Andrea B.

description: Cute restaurant on Haight street.  We had an early dinner here after a long day of walking and sightseeing.  So worth it!!  The salads and Veggie sandwiches were delicious.
author: Kim D.

description: This place should be called The Average instead of The Grind. Food isn't terrible if you get what you ordered...which didn't happen in my situation or the couple sitting next to me. Wrong toast and wrong potatoes in my case and completely wrong meal for the couple sitting next to me. The two girls working that day (one was a "manager"?!?!) needed to spend less time being giggly with the customers and more time paying attention to orders they take. The one saving grace for this place is the outdoor dining section...very nice place to sit and people watch.
author: Deidrich O.

description: Great spot for breakfast or lunch...or if you're like me and like breakfast for dinner sometimes :) A lot of variety and its all yummy...hot sandwiches, fresh salads, awesome omelettes, and the best burger in lower haight. Great go to spot
author: Shazia A.

description: This place is an extra block further from Fillmore than some of the other breakfast options in the lower haight, which is maybe why I had forgotten about it for awhile, but not anymore! I went yesterday and won't forget it again. I got the oatmeal with mixed fruit and it was great.
