My boyfriend got some platter of french toast, eggs, and home fries and he was delighted with the portion. Great spot, definitely worth checking out. It's an order-at-the-counter type place. They do have a nice little patio, and a huge assortment of fresh baked goodies! can't wait to go back and try one (or more)
author: Caitlin B.

description: im really surprised the grind isnt rated higher. the breakfast scrambles are great.. good portions and great flavor. they have a large menu of eggs, pancakes, pastries, etc. fairly large seating area and freshly brewed coffee in pint glasses. big fan.
author: Kelly N.

description:
1.  The people who work here are great.  Nice, friendly, helpful, sincere.  Andrea and Felicia are my favorite gals...
2.  Coffee is good.  
3.  Breakfasts are delicious.  I like the mixed plate with a little bit of everything: french toast, eggs, potatoes, bacon.  Breakfast burritos out of this world.  Egg dishes are good, too.
4.  Salads here are DELICIOUS.  Get it with chicken.  So yummy and huge and crisp.  Probably not for the diet conscious, though.
5.  Burgers are always nice.  I think they use Niman Ranch, too.
6.  French Fries here are my favorite.  Since I stopped eating McDonalds like 15 years ago, I've found the Grind's skinny fries to be the perfect replacement.
7.  Sandwiches are okay, so-so.  Don't love any that I've tried.
8.  They usually have 2 homemade soups each day
9.  They also have a happy hour where the alcohol is cheap.
10.  This place is recession proof

LOVE YOU!
author: erin k.

description:
This was a tough weekend.  By "tough" I mean mostly sleepless.  I did every debaucherous thing I possibly could and took bodily abuse to new levels.  It was fabulous!  At several points, however, I realized that my body needed nourishment.  As different groups of friends suggested eating here, I had the opportunity to dine two days in a row.  Day one saw me and a hot Austrian trying to force our e-xhausted bodies to consume nourishment.  He managed an orange banana smoothie while I was able to choke down the Pear Salad and some coffee.  I have to say that this was a super tasty salad and largely proportioned with a generous side of fresh sourdough.  Best of all, I survived to roll on to the Polk Street Fair!
Day two saw me roll in after a terribly strung out night after the Polk Street Festival which saw me greet the day at 7:30am before calling it a night.  I ordered the French Burger with fries and found it to be okay but nothing noteworthy.  The french fries were decent but I think it was a poor choice to order this variation of a hamburger as the addition of french bread makes for a heavier meal.  I couldn't finish the other half of my sandwich.
My friends who brought me here both days highly endorse the French Dip as being the best in the city.  I'll have to give this place another go-round and find out if that's true.
author: Jill D.

description: Yelp says that three starts is "A-OK", and that is exactly right. The Grind is okay. The don't mess up simple things like an omelet and hash browns, but its not out of this world. In such a foodie town, this is an okay place. Since the prices aren't any cheaper than anywhere else Im surprised its so popular. Last summer I did see Laura Linney and Ben Harper eating here, so thats a plus. If you are really hung over it will do.
author: Dana H.

description: Nish got it exactly right: Decent food at a nice price, and a comfy place to sit outside in the Haight on a sunny day.
author: Tal K.

description: 2pm on a Sunday, and there were open tables! Food is good and the portions are big and reasonably priced. Minus one star for small Mimosas but I'll be back.
author: Eric W.

description:
oh you, you little gem you. i never would have found you if it werent for my loooong days at the wak shack. you have fed me, nourished me, given me an excuse to leave work for twenty minutes and mostly just made my day too many times to count.
i love andrea. 
i like the boy with the blue eyes. 
and that i can always take two butters from the counter and no one cares. 
and that i always order the same three things and i love them.
the chicken ceaser, the breakfast sandwich, and the blta. i mean. its just gorgeous. 
i'll be seeing you on my mondays off. i;ll be the super hungover one on the OUTDOOR patio smoking and eating hella greasy eggs, looking over at the wak and being completely content that i dont have to go there anymore but i can come to the grind any ol' time.
author: Gabrielle k.

description: Excellent food. Very fresh, reasonably priced, really good selection. The outdoor tables are also really nice, especially for people watching. But....my huge stomach usually ends up bringing me to Kate's Kitchen instead for the portions.
author: Mark A.

description: man, why I was I so cranky the last time I reviewed this place? I love the Grind. I live in the neighborhood, so the baristas know me and are always friendly. That said, you shouldn't be in a rush for your coffee, they are SLOOOOW
author: Decades L.

description: crazy ridiculous annoying lines here all of the time BUT the pastries and coffee are well worth it!
author: R T.

description: The grind used to be dismal, but they remodeled, and it's now bright and cheery with a pleasant buzz about it. The food takes no risks -- it's straight up comfort food, but done perfectly well.  Some tasty breakfast items: Corn beef hash and eggs with a healthy dose of tobasco, chicken fried steak with thick flour gravy.
author: nicky c.

description: Best breakfast burrito I have ever had!! And the coffee is delicious too. Stopped by on a Monday morning and the place was busy and a bit louder than I prefer, so we did take-out and walked over to Duboce park to enjoy our food.
author: Meg J.

description:
It's my neighborhood joint, my stumble out of bed and get a cup of coffee place, but it's really too pricey. An omelet and coffee are more than $10, which may be okay for the oh-so-important SF Sunday brunch, but for a Thursday morning, it's pretty steep. The front desk staff seem nice, and for the most part, know the menu well. The guys that work in the kitchen are nice. The food is fine, but not spectacular. I would love a soy meat option like they have (or used to have) at other spots. There are several places to have brunch on Haight Street on Sundays, and I would put this up there pretty highly. If you get there at the right time, it's not as crowded as Kate's and the Squat n Gobble. 
I'd give it five stars if they added some soy protein and lowered the prices just a little.
author: Marge S.

description: Yay!! This place is no longer dingy and gross. After their recent remodel, it's turned into a lovely, clean cafe with plenty of great outdoor seating. I just come here for the coffee and to meet up with people. For that, this place has earned its four stars. This is review is not for the food at all b/c I have no idea if that's good or not.
author: Kimi W.

description:
i see that most people who have reviewed the grind talk about the coffee and breakfasts but i'm here to tell all of you that the salads are amazing.

seriously, unless you go to a sit down place, i think it is hard to find a reseasonably priced salads that use super fresh ingrediants. look no more, the grind has come to the rescue. my favorites are the pear salad or the veggie (kind of a redundant name but you know..) salad. and of course i add grilled chicken which is always tender and cooked to order.

on top of this, i've found the staff to be outgoing and friendly. thank you, the grind!
author: gina s.

description: This place is reliable. I love the chicks who work there. They are cute and funny. The food is solid and I especially enjoy the Pear Salad when I want to feel a little healthier than I normally am. This is the spot that I enjoy thoroughly because it is so close to my house. There are certainly better spots for breakfast in the city but The Grind holds a special place in my heart.
author: N S.

description: I grew up two blocks away from The Grind and have been going since they opened.  I really like the open feel of the caf and the staff have always been really nice. They have a great set of choices on the menu, plus all the goodies you can look at while in line. When I'm on the healthy mode I shoot for the granola / yogurt / fruit bowl. I have never had such an amazing granola bowl in my life! The granola is really good plus there is more fruit then I know what to do with.  The lox bagel is my next favorite, it is just packed full of goodness!
author: Susannah M.

description: I love The Grind Cafe. I live really close by and it's so nice to be able to walk over within a minute or two. The folks are always friendly and if you're a regular coffee drinker, they'll remember and offer you recommendations on what you might like to try. The Sister and I loved the granola with yogurt and fresh fruit. Ask for a little bit more yogurt when you order though. It comes with strawberries, blueberries and bananas and at the very end I like to mix in some honey (when all of the fruit except the bananas is gone). The coffee is mediocre but the scramblers are yummy. I like the Grind Scram. Get it with the hash browns and sourdough toast and then eat the latter with a little butter and a lot of blackberry jam and you're all set! Viva la breakfast!
author: Christine P.

description: Excellent coffee. Great atmosphere. Friendly staff. Scrumptious food. Try the spinach salad and the vast array of baked goods.
author: grep d.

description: Your basic nice cafe for breakfast or lunch. I like going here for weekend brunch, because it has good breakfast basics and is really airy and spacious. Affordable. I agree that the art on the walls is pretty mediocre. It seems like they could do much better with all the great artists here in SF.
author: Cyrelle D.

description: Great location and cool outdoor seating but that's about all that I really liked about this place.  The chicken fried steak was great but there's just not enough of it.  The food was just ok.  Nothing really stuck out as being incredible in any way.  The coffee was *terrible*.  Bagels were "enh".  I'm definitely a much bigger fan of Squat and Gobble down the street.
author: Cyan C.

description: With the remodel the place looks really nice.  I got a delicious cupcake and a mocha that I couldn't finish.  I'd like to come back and have a full breakfast.
author: Lauren S.

description: I love the grind. The atmosphere, the service, and the fact that it's changed so much over the last seven years has been good for it. It's certainly cleaned up since 2002. I like the smoothies, coffee, granola & yoghurt, sausages, and other breakfast items. I have also had the burger and it was good. It has a good line up to keep you well fed if you happen to stay a few hours. The patio outside is nice, too. I come here often just to study and read on my laptop when it's not too busy. Rush hours are weekends after 10am. Get there early and you get the place to yourself with a few other early birds. :)
author: Sari S.

description: I lived in this neighborhood before it had a name and this was the closest place to get a meal. Now I know places change and things change but I miss the Grind. I could wander in for lunch or in the morning for a bagel and coffee sit at a table and not be bothered. So great. I am not a huge fan of the remodel but  I can still get the breakfast sandwich when I am in the neighborhood.
author: Seamus M.

description: Great little spot in Lower Haight.  I had the garden burger and it was good, very good.  I could tell they select good quality products.  On top of this, I thought the place was reasonably priced. Also, must mention they have a patio.  Go on a nice sunny day and sit on the patio.
author: Eduardo A.

description: I had the good fortune of getting to live right down the street from The Grind for the first year I lived in San Francisco.   The Grind is so awesome!!  Great croissant sandwiches, great coffee, great tea, and great fresh squeezed orange juice!  I highly highly recommend this place for breakfast, brunch, or just a quick cup of coffee.  I never had dinner here, but I'm sure it would be delicious.
author: TK B.

description: chicken breast sucked and the place was dirty. If there was a negative -1 star I would give it.
author: Michael S.

description:
normal breakfast fair.  i felt like it took a little longer than it should have to get our food but that also could have been bc I was really hungry.  

I went with a veggie egg white omelet... it tasted exactly like you think it would.  the place was pretty packed so it's a decent people watching locale, especially if you get a table outside.  solid, reliable little place.
author: Marc H.

description: I can see why some of the reviews give it some knocks on decor and what-not...but overall, when looking for a neighborhood "catch carry-all" food place the Grind hits it.  Breakfasts are never asthetically pleasing but they get it right with taste.  The lunch menu is equally not impressivly presented but I've never had a complaint with any of the food I've ordered.  Basically, this is a neighborhood thing...the looks are utalitarian but the food ranks up there with tried and true.  They are remodeling in winter of 2006 and if it looks anything like its affiliate Toast, in Noe Valley, this place will catch on for those that decor mens more than tastyness.
author: Chris D.

description: Open at 7am on Saturdays, this may become a destination for us early risers.  Having no expectations, they were readily exceeded.  This is some good quality food with decent portions.
author: Esther R.

description: The best Chai in the lower Haight, except for maybe Cafe International. Also a nice spot to watch people doing the walk of shame on weekend mornings. Food is just ok - I try to stick to the baked goods. Thems the goods!
author: Colleen B.

description: good breakfast/brunch, if i'm getting breakfast on a sat/dun morning, this is typically where i go
author: Michael E.

description:
great place for breakfast or lunch when you're just strollin' around on a lazy day. free wireless woohoo! great coffee. outdoor seating & friendly staff :)

only thing is that sometimes the food can be a bit greasy & the service isn't always consistent.
author: Rosalynn D.

description: They remodeled. They raised their prices, but it's still pretty much the same. A good stand-by, but the food is average, and so is the coffee. Always super crowded on weekend mornings.
author: katie p.

description: I live across from The Grind and spend quite a bit of time there so sometimes I want to try something new but the more I venture out to spend time in other cafes the more I realize the Grind is still the best.  Free good working Wi-Fi, plenty of power outlets, a nice staff of friendly girls, a full breakfast and lunch menu with great choices of good tasting food, beer, wine, open early, outside seating, accepts debit cards, big windows, good music, clean tables (good bus boy service), great selection of sweets, easy to customize your order, free range burgers... I could go on and on.. Although some places have similar offerings, NONE of them are consistent with all of these... i.e. bad Wi-Fi or no debit cards, or no outlet privilege, no customizing your order.  The Grind is the BEST CAFE IN SF!!!! No comparison.  The only thing I wish is that they brought back the Guayaki Mate into their menu.  Please bring it back!
author: Miguel S.

description: I am one of those people who eat the same thing every day. When I lived on Haight, I went to The Grind for a side of wheat toast and a cup of coffee for breakfast like clockwork every. single. day. I was a little embarrassed that they wouldn't even ask me what I wanted, just "the usual?" but hey, they were always so friendly and nice! For some reason I hate eating at home and this place was perfect. I wanted to eat my toast at Cafe Grind. I guess I just loved the atmosphere there. The only drawback was that on weekend afternoons, it was so crowded that sometimes there would be no place to sit.
author: -kiko- S.

description: I love this place.  It has such a vast menu - something to please even the most picky eaters (which I know from personal experience, so trust me).  The vanilla latte is very good here, and I've been twice already for breakfast.  The veggie bagel with hummus and sprouts is positively delicious.  My husband and I had brunch there today and he enjoyed the lower haight omelet and I the tofu scram.  My husband commented that his omelet was "awesome" and completely cleaned off his plate.  The tofu scram was great, the first time I've tried it actually, and I think it's a great vegan-friendly dish, which is definitely hard to find.  Both dishes come on a big plate, with a side of toast or muffin, and hash browns, salad, or fries.  We had the hash browns and they were great.  Service is friendly and in addition to the great menu, this place also is loaded with fine pastries, cookies, and more.  A great place for lunch or breakfast or just a quick cup of coffee!
author: Beenish K.

description: I dubbed this place my office, about 8 months ago.  Then I had to change my morning venues and cuisine.  I swear by their granola bowl with yogurt and fresh fruit.  They give you enough -no joke-That will choke any dirty hippie.  This family service operation is great and they are always respectful to their regulars.  If only if they were on the sunny side of the street, Sorry Ney-Ney!!!
author: jonathan b.

description: Great spot for a laid-back weekend brunch. It was fairly busy (a good sign, I always say) but we were able to snag a table on the patio and people watch while we waited for our food. I had the Haight scramble (bacon, avacado, green onion, cheddar) with home fries and my husband had a Belgian waffle with a side of bacon, and everything was delicious. Will definitely be back. Although next time I'm getting the Nutella Madness - buttermilk pancakes with bananas and nutella, YUM!
author: Meghan C.

description: I tend to frequent this place a lot because it is 50 yards away from my house. The coffee is good if they decided to make it right. The breakfast platters are tasty but a little pricey. The sandwiches are pretty good but again a little on the expensive side for what they are. It's a little dirty inside but then again so am I.
author: Sal B.

description: The Grind just got a major facelift and, surprisingly, the menu didn't seem to double in price like most places do when they remodel. The decor is much more upscale and clean than the shabby old brown walls and bad art used to be, and the food does the trick for standard breakfast fare, sandwiches, and salads. I hadn't been there in a few years and am happy to have it back on my radar.
author: guinevere h.

description: The food here is freaking awesome! Nice place to waltz over to on Saturday morning for breakfast. The Breakfast Burrito = tasty hangeover cure. Timely service and great patio place to sit/eat/people watch at.
author: Alex P.

description:
i miss the old Grind.  the grimy grind.  i do like the orange mosaic counters, but overall, i miss the old grime.  this place is too bright now, too sterile, and doesn't really fit the lower-haight vibe. i do like the free wifi tho, since now i am DSL-less and a wifi nomad (see Oakside Cafe review), but i don't like the fact that they close at 6pm.  seems weird to close so early, esp on lower haight.  when i've been there lately, i've seen a ton of people come around 6pm only to be told they're closed.  seems like they're losing out on some key biz, but whatever....

another thing i don't like about the new grind is that it seems like they put in a crappier ventilation system w/ the remodel - it flatout stinks in there, a collage of fried/burnt food stink, and i always come out smelling like the stink.  yuk.  maybe once the weather gets warmer and they can open up the windows, it'll get better...one can only hope...or they'll be calling me Pepe Le Sue...
author: Suzanne A.

description: Mmmmm yummy - I like the 2 eagle breakfast scrambled with cheddar cheese, wheat toast, and chicken apple sausage.  The portions are big which is nice, but it's a tad pricey (probably $10-$12 for breakfast and a juice) - I think it's worth it
author: Jared F.

description: The girl behind the counter was nice and greeted us with a smile. The cooks were friendly and seemed to enjoy working there. The seating area was clean. I had ordered the Reuben sandwich and overall it was up to par to other Reubens I've had. The big disappointment for me was that what I got didn't match the description on the wall menu. The wall menu definitely said it came with tomatoes and lettuce (which I thought was unusual for a Reuben). The sandwich that came out didn't have tomatoes. Like I said, it was good but I would have really liked to try it with tomatoes. Since it's sort of out of the way for me, I wouldn't make the trip over here again unless I was already in the area.
author: Jane K.

description:
i dont frequent this end of the Haight that much, the 400-500 blocks are really where 80% of Lower Haight businesses are.

at any rate, been here only a few times over the last several years. the front patio is nice. you can drink your beverage, grab a bite to eat (decent sandwiches) and people watch.

the odd thing is, all the hundreds of time i have driven in front of the place, i always glance over and feel like i need to pull up grab sumfin' -but then again, im always on a mission racing up the street to go do an errand. on the way back when racing down, i only have tunnel vision, i.e., to find freekin' parking close to my place. so basically, i dont really give rats ass on stopping here............................................*sorry*
author: Sha A.

description: The Grind is good for food in general, I'm taking away a star because damn has it gotten pricey. Great for breakfast, brunch and lunch mostly, but it has pretty good coffee, Mr. Espresso, and a great selection of sandwiches. The chicken salad is pretty good, and they do have a decent cheesesteak if that's what you're looking for. I like how you can sit outside and they also have free Wi-Fi, so I've just sat there and looked for a job all hours until about 5pm. The cashier people are really nice and always cute and young!
author: Gina R.

description: I had an awesome greasy ham and cheese omelet there after a night out and it was killer.  Greasy fried spuds and gooey cheese.  Have never had the coffee but the OJ was mighty good.  Great neighborhood spot.
author: Nicole F.

description: I was pretty disappointed with this place. The place was mobbed which led me to believe it was going to be some stellar eats. I ordered the pesto chicken sandwich which was hot and melty - a good start. The pesto sauce was pretty bland though and the french fries were sub par. I bought a slice of the Fudgie Wudgie cake expecting awesomeness but again was let down with its blandness. I have a pretty vicious sweet tooth but forgot to eat the remainder of it until about three days later.
author: Andrew M.

description: Great little coffee house/breakfast place. I feel like I am in a San Francisco version of Sex in the City when I'm here with my friends. The only thing I didn't enjoy was my mocha... it wasn't quite as good or chocolate rich as lets say Pete's Coffee or Starbucks. They have a great breakfast menu and all my friends enjoyed the atmosphere and they enjoyed their meals. If I am ever in the area again I'll walk... finding parking took about 5-8 minutes just like everywhere else here. Next time it will be a good walk...
author: Evan T.

description: Everyone elses food looked great! I ordered an omlette with high expectations. It wasnt wonderful, but not really bad either. But I like to go places and eat things that I couldnt easily cook at home myself.
author: Misty D.

description: Wow.  After hearing great things about this place I was seriously disappointed.  I went there for breakfast to find that the prices and quality of the food left much to be desired.  First of all, a breakfast sandwich, egg, meat and cheese will run you $8.  Yes, $8.  You can get a cheap one at Lee's for $2.85 or just about any other place in the city for less than $5.  There is nothing special about the food, average at best, and about 50% overpriced.  There is no reason a coffee and small breakfast should cost over $10, especially in the lower haight.
author: Eli Z.

description: Just had breakfast there. Very disappointing. Hash browns were insitutional fries (the kind you buy at Costco in 3-ton boxes), eggs were undercooked and watery, bread was lousy and under-butterred, cappucino was strange, and my stomach is in pain 2 hours later. I would not return.
author: Eater S.

description: As a carnivore, I rarely get a vegetarian anything.  Why the hell should I give up my 'Darwinian' advantage?  Anyway I always get the Veggie Sandwich here,  It's bueno.   They have nice teas.  Service is tad slow but not enough to gripe about.   Nice skylight and good outdoor patio if the wind would ever die in SF.
author: jack w.

description: I just got a pastrami sandwich and a salad here; pretty simple.  Both were very good.  I liked the bread and the salad was pretty big.  The vegetables seemed fresh.  Seemed like a nice place.
author: Stephen S.

description:
I was here on new years day, my birthday! 
Had slept late at the hotel I will review on another page and needed food. This was my first time back in SF in almost 10 years and I was very excited to head for the Height section of the city, everyone is so creative and fun.
We were driving up towards Ashbury and this place looked so cute and friendly we just had to stop.
You go up to the counter and order then find a table on your own and sit. This is normally cool except there were no tables to sit at, for a half an hour. Which didn't matter I guess because we still hadn't been served by then. So we finally find one that has just been abandoned out on the patio and continue to wait another half hour or so for our food. 
I had the French Toast with Hash Browns and a side of scrambled egg, my man had the Corned Beef Hash on Toast. I don't know how long it took altogether about an hour and a half, but for average food this was a really annoying experience. 
The people were all nice and even fellow customers, it is tiny and it was new years, but come on guys pick up the pace a little!
author: Sydney C.

description: God bless you, The Grind. You're 50 meters from my house and you never let me down. The staff are lovely, the food is not out of this world but it does the job and sometimes a bit more. I've eaten here a hundred times and maybe only once been disappointed. They do a solid burger and the Grind Combo is a hangover cure from heaven - eggs, sausage or bacon, pancakes or French toast, what's not to like. So the omelets are a bit rubbery but dude this ain't Paris and the portions are grand. And it's big enough that you have a chance of getting breakfast without waiting a lifetime at the weekends.
author: mefloquine x.

description: The Grind serves a purpose for me and it serves it well - that's why it gets 4 stars.  It gives me a salad I really like in a location where there are not too many options.  Plus, I always run into people there.  All the salads are good, my favorite being the veggie delight with chicken.  French Dip sandwich is good.  I'm not totally sold on their breakfast.  Omelets are too thin.  Otherwise, I dig the art, I dig the people watching, and the staff is much nicer than they seem once you get to know them.  They kind of have that East Coast roughness, which can rub some San Franciscans the wrong way.
author: Michael M.

description: I have only had breakfast there but it was OK. I had an Denver omelette, with english muffin and fruit cup.  The omelette was pretty full... complete with egg shell.  The fruit cup was large cereal bowl large but cost a $1.50 more to substitute for potatoes. The ice tea was a little bitter but at least they had lemon.   I wouldn't make a special trip to there but if you are in the neighborhood not a bad choice.
author: Kevin C.

description: ive never had a bad breakfast at the grind. always pleasant and comfortable. i never have to wait too long and its very well priced. they got all the usual stuff you might find at any normal breakfast spot but this place always comes through. if you're looking for breakfast in the lower haight this is the place. sure beats waiting in line for an hour at other spots (except the porkstore which i will gladly wait in line for). the outdoor seating is a very nice touch on a sunny day also.
author: Andrew D.

description: Best breakfast burrito I've had outside of Santa Fe, NM.  The salsa tastes like it's homemade from roasted chiles and lot's of love.  This is no dry-scrambled-eggs-and-canned-salsa-in-a-dry-tortilla.  The Grind breakfast burrito is the real deal.   Love the staff too.
author: M H.

description: despite the line out the door, the cheery indie women running the register and stirring out espresso beverages laughed as my boyfriend and I stammered through all of the options to have our eggs.  not just a place for brunch, famed for fresh salads, on-the-hip-side clientel, and a good roast, this place serves up some delicious grub. if you order the pancakes or french toast, don't forget to serve yourself some always hot syrup from the counter, and if it's sunny enough, enjoy a great street patio with outdoor seating.
author: Rachel R.

description: This place reminds me of a Southern Louisiana Victorian bordello. Really cool looking on the outside, unsavoriness on the inside. Coffee is average coffeeshop fare, baked goods are REALLY good. But, Im trying to think up the ways to fuck up an iced chai. I ordered a large coffee, and my friend ordered an iced chai. What she got was a HOT chai, with a shot of espresso. o.0 Neither one of us noticed that she put the espresso in, but it was obviously hot. "Excuse me, she ordered an iced chai." The nice girl says, "No she didnt, she ordered a chai with a shot of espresso." I was like..."I dont know how, but i think you heard her wrong." Shes all snottily "No, i didnt, but ill make another." I was like "Dude, she doesnt even drink coffee, and why would you put a shot of espress..urgh...fine." She flipped her hair, and said "Well, you wanna make sure she doesnt want espresso?" So i turn 3 degrees to the left. She shakes her head no. Turn back to girl. "No she doesnt." Yikes. Coffee girl rolls eyes and sighs like a teenager at family game night. Sweet coffee girl, i can appreciate mishearing someone like anyone's bidness, and thats no big. But dont make us feel like dicks. If youre coming into my hood, check your tude at Lombard.
author: Mick F.

description: Delicious...had a turkey sandwich there today and it was awesome. Outdoor patio area is sweet and the food never disappoints. Live in the area and this is our go to spot on the weekends for breakfast or lunch. Plus the service is good and the nice young lady working at the counter was sexy-sexy.
author: Mike S.

description: This place is great. Coffee was very good. I know good coffee is not hard to come by in San Francisco but I have to admit while visiting I paid this place a few visits. Breakfast you can't beat! They have almost everything on the menu. Never could get past breakfast although lunch had some nice choices. Friendly service and a happy hour! What else could you ask for? I still think about the coffee from time to time.
author: Joanna H.

description: It is a cute, cozy little neighborhood spot with lots of yummy choices. We walked down and ordered the Haight Scramble and the strawberry waffles. The only reason I give this place 4 stars is because the order got mixed up. They brought us over the pancakes instead of waffles and it took another 15 mintues just to get them...worth the wait though. The staff are extremely polite and very cheery for a dreary Monday morning. Definitely in a "food coma" right now...gotta go walk it off.
author: Morgan G.

description: stopped into the Grind today for my first time. even though I only had a  bagel and some oj, i'd totally go back. i just wasn't that hungry and honestly, i was using them for their free wi-fi. anyways, the girl working was hella nice and my bagel was ready before I even sat down. ok, so, i was busy putting sugar in my free coffee (some movie promotion dude was there giving out free coffee and taking pics) and well, of course getting my picture taken, kinda weird, but whateves.
author: Lola D.

description: yummy salads [i recommend their poppy seed dressing].  terrible breakfast.  stroll down haight to squat & gobble or kate's kitchen.  the wait at kate's is better than the bland breakfasts at the grind.
author: Mary S.

description:
Kids Menu for a bribe
I went to the counter and ordered the Kids Plate of chicken nuggets and French fries with a juice box.  The person taking my order rolled her eyes and stated that this is only for kids eight and under and you can not order the Kids Plate.  Age for placing a kids order was not stated on the menu so I bribed her an extra dollar to have a taste of this world famous Kids Menu plus with some extra attitude on the side. She was glade to take the bribe and I soon was sitting with my world famous Kids Plate, but I saw that I did not have my juice box.  Back at the counter I asked on the juice box but the workers said we do not have a jukebox.  I restated the question, but they did not know what a juice box was or what it even looked like.  I did not carry the argument any further because I wanted to get back to my world famous Kids Plate.  It was just like I had dreamed; the fries had the taste of hot oiled paper and the nuggets were shaped like small dinosaurs just like the ones from Costco.  I think I will not order the famous Kids Plate again and just go to Costco and pick me up 1000 pieces of dinosaur and on the way out a hot dog and drink.
author: jon f.

description:
this is a really good place to take your friends who eat completely different from you, because there is a little bit of eveything on the menu. 

they do good espresso but the coffee was not so great.

the food is very good and the service was good, i went in on a busy sunday morning and got my food in about 15 minutes which i thought was great seeing as how there were dozens of others who had arrived before me.
author: Sasha R.

description: the girl with the long curlyish dark hair is MEAN and the eggs are like rubber. this is coming from someone who lives in the neighborhood and has accidentally tried eating here more than a few times. i don't get why everyone is so stoked on this place, I'd get a better meal if i made it with Play-Doh.
author: otto v.
